title: EPIC: Conformance, Differential Fuzzing, and Test Completeness
description:
Background:
Port correctness is proven, not asserted. We need fixture parity, stochastic drift detection, and detailed diagnostics for fast triage.

Goal:
Build full test stack: unit, invariant, stress, e2e, conformance, and differential fuzzing with minimization.

Key requirement:
Tests and scripts must produce rich logs/artifacts so failures are actionable and reproducible.

Why this serves users:
- high confidence in semantic faithfulness
- lower MTTR for regressions
- safer optimization velocity.

Cross-cutting quality contract:
- Child tasks must define and link unit tests, e2e script coverage (when behavioral), and structured log/manifest artifacts or explicit rationale for non-applicability.
- Completion evidence must remain compatible with bd-66l.9 enforcement and traceability index expectations.

title: Build Rust reference fixture capture tooling for kernel semantics
description:
Background:
Conformance depends on a trusted Rust behavior oracle encoded as canonical fixtures. This bead is the tooling foundation used by fixture-capture streams.

Subtasks:
- Implement fixture capture program skeleton, canonical schema writer, and provenance metadata emitter.
- Implement deterministic capture execution pipeline with stable scenario IDs and seeds.
- Provide capture CLI interfaces used by core/robustness/vertical fixture-family tasks.
- Document tooling usage and output contracts for downstream conformance/e2e stages.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Tooling can capture and emit schema-valid canonical fixture artifacts reproducibly.
- Outputs include provenance and version metadata.
- Downstream fixture-family tasks (bd-1md.13..bd-1md.15) can execute against this tooling contract.
close_reason: Published deterministic fixture capture tooling contract (CLI + pipeline + provenance), added canonical manifest/fixture schemas, and wired traceability links for downstream fixture-family beads

title: Implement canonical e2e scenario script suite with deterministic run-manifest artifacts
description:
Background:
The plan requires comprehensive e2e coverage with rich diagnostics; this bead is an aggregation checkpoint over dedicated e2e script families.

- Standardize script inputs (seed, scenario pack, profile, codec, resource class) and output locations.

Acceptance Criteria:
- E2E scripts are one-command reproducible locally and in CI.
- Every failing e2e run writes complete logs and artifact manifests.
- Scripts are mapped to hard gates and release verification workflows.
- Completion requires all e2e family streams (bd-1md.16..bd-1md.18) to be merged and validated.

title: Implement structured test-log schema and artifact taxonomy for unit/invariant/conformance/e2e

Background:
Detailed logging is only useful if schema and artifact taxonomy are stable and machine-readable.

Subtasks:
- Define JSONL log schema with required fields: ts, run_id, scenario_id, subsystem, profile, codec, seed, event_index, digest, status, and error metadata.
- Define artifact taxonomy and retention policy for stdout/stderr, trace snapshots, parity diffs, minimizer outputs, and replay bundles.
- Add validators that fail CI when required log fields/artifacts are missing.
- Document log interpretation playbook for rapid triage and regression localization.

Acceptance Criteria:
- All test layers emit schema-compliant logs.
- CI can detect malformed or incomplete artifacts automatically.
- Operators and maintainers can debug failures from artifacts without rerunning immediately.

title: Implement unit/invariant completeness matrix with per-module test obligations and drift checks

Background:
Comprehensive tests require an explicit completeness matrix so coverage does not drift as modules grow.

Subtasks:

- Map obligations to concrete test files/cases and parity fixtures.

Acceptance Criteria:

title: EPIC: Spec Foundation and Plan-Space Canonicalization
description:
Background:
This project is explicitly spec-first. The C implementation must be derived from extracted semantics, not line-by-line translation from Rust source.

Goal:
Produce a self-contained canonical spec suite so implementation can proceed without consulting legacy Rust internals.

Must cover (non-negotiable):
- COMPLETE lifecycle semantics for region/task/obligation/cancellation
- outcome lattice and budget algebra
- forbidden-behavior catalog (must-fail matrix)
- machine-readable invariant schema
- scenario DSL and fixture contracts
- guarantee-substitution mapping (Rust guarantees -> C mechanisms)
- explicit exclusions/deferred surfaces and open decisions

Why this serves users:
- prevents semantic drift and accidental feature amputation
- enables predictable implementation and review
- allows independent auditors/future maintainers to understand intent without archaeology.

Cross-cutting quality contract:
- Child tasks must define and link unit tests, e2e script coverage (when behavioral), and structured log/manifest artifacts or explicit rationale for non-applicability.
- Completion evidence must remain compatible with bd-66l.9 enforcement and traceability index expectations.

title: Create exhaustive docs/EXISTING_ASUPERSYNC_STRUCTURE.md as canonical extracted semantics

This is the primary extraction artifact and must be complete enough that implementation does not require reading legacy Rust code. It is an aggregation checkpoint over dedicated extraction streams.

title: Operationalize risk controls for performance tails and adaptive-controller complexity
description:

title: Create docs/C_PORTABILITY_RULES.md and enforce UB-elimination contract
description:

title: Create docs/FEATURE_PARITY.md with semantic-unit tracking and acceptance tests
description:
Background:
FEATURE_PARITY.md is the live semantic scoreboard for the port and must encode review/provenance status, not just implementation status.

title: Execute Phase 1 spec-review gate with independent verifier sign-off
description:
Background:
Plan phase 1 now requires independent review before phase 2 opens, to prevent expensive spec drift defects.

All 19 kernel-scope units at spec-reviewed status. Phase 2 kickoff approved. Review artifact: docs/PHASE1_SPEC_REVIEW_GATE.md

title: Author machine-readable invariant schema and generation pipeline

Background:
Invariant drift is a primary risk. Machine-readable schema enables generated tests and CI drift gates.

Schema baseline hash committed for CI drift detection.

title: Define forbidden-behavior catalog + shared scenario DSL
description:
Background:
Faithfulness requires explicit definition of what must fail, not only what should succeed.

title: Publish Rust->C guarantee-substitution matrix and anti-butchering enforcement contract

title: Create plan-to-execution traceability index (claims -> beads -> tests -> artifacts)

title: Create profile companion docs: EMBEDDED_TARGET_PROFILES, HFT_PROFILE, AUTOMOTIVE_PROFILE

title: EPIC: Runtime Kernel, Scheduling, Cancellation, Timer, and Channel Semantics
description:
Background:
Kernel behavior is where semantic fidelity is most fragile: ordering, cancellation, and queueing rules can silently diverge.

Goal:
Implement deterministic kernel loop and channel/timer semantics with rigorous fairness/starvation and correctness checks.

Must include:
- deterministic tie-break and event sequencing
- cancellation propagation checkpoints
- timer wheel semantics and O(1) cancel behavior
- bounded two-phase MPSC semantics

Why this serves users:
- reproducible behavior for incident analysis
- robust performance and correctness on both low-latency and constrained hardware.

Cross-cutting quality contract:
- Child tasks must define and link unit tests, e2e script coverage (when behavioral), and structured log/manifest artifacts or explicit rationale for non-applicability.
- Completion evidence must remain compatible with bd-66l.9 enforcement and traceability index expectations.

title: Implement arena-backed region/task/obligation tables with generation-safe handles
description:
Background:
Runtime storage for lifecycle entities must be performant and safe under churn, cancellation, and reuse.

Subtasks:
- Implement arena-backed table structures for regions, tasks, and obligations.
- Enforce generation-safe handle validation on every access path.
- Integrate debug quarantine behavior for hardening mode.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Table operations are deterministic and test-covered.
- Handle reuse and stale-handle cases are explicitly validated.
- No direct external mutable references escape API boundaries.
close_reason: done

title: Implement deterministic scheduler loop with stable tie-break ordering and event sequencing
description:
Background:
Scheduler ordering drift is a primary semantic regression vector and must be tightly controlled.

Subtasks:
- Implement deterministic ready/cancel/timed lane processing rules.
- Define stable tie-break ordering for simultaneous events.
- Emit deterministic sequencing metadata suitable for replay identity.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Same input and seed produce identical ordered event streams.
- Ordering rules are documented and fixture-tested.
- No hidden nondeterminism from container iteration order.
close_reason: done

title: Implement cancellation propagation, checkpoints, and bounded cleanup semantics
description:
Background:
Cancellation is central to asupersync semantics and must preserve bounded cleanup with explicit phase behavior.

Subtasks:
- Implement cancellation propagation through region/task relationships.
- Implement task-visible checkpoint API and phase transitions.
- Verify cleanup boundaries and obligations under cancel storms.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Cancel behavior matches fixture expectations for edge ordering cases.
- Cleanup remains bounded and deterministic.
- All cancel-phase transitions are legality-checked.

title: Implement timer wheel semantics with deterministic ordering and O(1) cancel by validated handle
description:
Background:
Timer behavior affects fairness, deadline semantics, and replay fidelity.

Subtasks:
- Implement timer insertion/fire/cancel semantics with explicit ordering rules.
- Enforce generation-validated cancel handles.
- Add boundary tests for churn and cancellation races.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Timer ordering is deterministic for same inputs.
- Cancel operations are O(1) by design and measured.
- Failure behavior on invalid handles is stable and explicit.

title: Build small-state exhaustive scheduler checker and cycle-budget checkpoint validation
description:
Background:
Random tests miss starvation and fairness corner cases; small-state exhaustive analysis is required.

Subtasks:
- Build bounded state-space explorer for scheduler transitions.
- Validate fairness/starvation properties against expected invariants.
- Validate cycle-budget checkpoint behavior under low-frequency CPU assumptions.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Checker catches seeded adversarial ordering bugs.
- Output includes minimized counterexample traces for failures.
- Results are reproducible and CI-friendly.

title: Implement bounded MPSC two-phase channel (reserve/send/abort) with FIFO and wakeup correctness
description:
Background:
Two-phase channel semantics are key to obligation linearity and correctness under backpressure.

Subtasks:
- Implement reserve/send/abort transitions and legality checks.
- Enforce bounded capacity behavior and deterministic rejection/backpressure semantics.
- Validate FIFO and wakeup behavior under concurrent producer patterns.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Channel conformance fixtures pass for success/failure paths.
- No illegal state transitions survive API boundaries.
- Detailed logs exist for deadlock/starvation debugging in tests.
close_reason: done

title: Implement optional parallel profile with worker model, lane rules, and fairness validation
description:
Background:
Phase 8 is optional but must be planned with strict parity constraints relative to deterministic single-thread mode.

Subtasks:
- Implement worker model and lane scheduling rules for ready/cancel/timed work.
- Implement bounded fairness controls and test harnesses.
- Validate no semantic regression in deterministic single-thread profile.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Parallel profile is feature-flagged and isolated from core mode.
- Fairness tests pass for enabled paths.
- Deterministic profile behavior remains unchanged.

title: EPIC: Dual Codec (JSON/BIN), Trace, Replay, and Continuity
description:
Background:
JSON-first comparison and optimized binary transport must coexist without semantic divergence.

Goal:
Deliver codec abstraction, trace/replay pipeline, and crash/restart continuity with canonical semantic digests.

Guarantee:
Codec choice may affect throughput/footprint only; it may not alter semantic outcomes.

Why this serves users:
- JSON enables inspectability and easier parity debugging
- binary enables production efficiency
- replay continuity supports post-failure forensics.

Cross-cutting quality contract:
- Child tasks must define and link unit tests, e2e script coverage (when behavioral), and structured log/manifest artifacts or explicit rationale for non-applicability.
- Completion evidence must remain compatible with bd-66l.9 enforcement and traceability index expectations.

title: Implement codec abstraction and canonical schema model with JSON baseline
description:
Background:
JSON-first is required for transparent parity bring-up and debugging. It establishes semantic baseline before binary optimization.

Subtasks:
- Implement codec abstraction interface and canonical message schema model.
- Implement JSON encode/decode path for fixtures and trace tooling.
- Validate deterministic serialization of semantic fields and stable error surfaces.

Acceptance Criteria:
- JSON codec passes schema validation and fixture replay tests.
- No semantic fields are codec-specific.
- Decoder failure behavior is deterministic and documented.
close_reason: Implemented codec abstraction + canonical fixture schema model with JSON encode/decode baseline; deterministic replay key and unit/conformance tests validated via rch make build/test.

title: Implement optimized binary codec (length-delimited, compact fields, checksum, safe zero-copy paths)
description:
Background:
Binary mode is needed for throughput/latency/footprint gains while preserving exact semantics.

Subtasks:
- Implement frame format with message type and schema versioning.
- Implement compact field encoding and optional integrity footer/checksum.
- Implement safe zero-copy decode for hot payloads where invariants permit.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Binary codec round-trips all canonical schema fields.
- Version mismatch and corruption paths are deterministic and test-covered.
- Performance intent is measurable with benchmark fixtures.
close_reason: Completed: binary frame codec with schema/version/checksum, zero-copy decode view, and deterministic corruption/version/truncation coverage

title: Implement cross-codec semantic equivalence and digest identity checks
description:
Background:
Codec choice must never alter semantics; only operational envelope may differ.

Subtasks:
- Build equivalence runner for JSON versus binary outputs on identical scenarios.
- Compute canonical semantic digests and compare across codecs.
- Emit clear diff artifacts for mismatch triage.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Shared scenario set has matching canonical digests for JSON and binary.
- Mismatch reports are minimized and actionable.
- Integrated into conformance and CI gate flows.
close_reason: done

title: Implement deterministic event emission format, replay mode, and snapshot/export hooks
description:
Background:
Replayability is a cornerstone guarantee for debugging, auditing, and regression analysis.

Subtasks:
- Implement deterministic event record format and hash-chain output.
- Implement replay input mode with verification of expected state/snapshot.
- Implement snapshot/export hooks needed for conformance and tooling.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Same seed/input replays to identical digest and final snapshot.
- Replay mismatch diagnostics identify first divergence point.
- Tooling outputs are machine-readable and CI-usable.

title: Implement crash/restart replay continuity package for persisted scenarios
description:
Background:
Real systems restart and can lose power mid-write; semantic continuity across restart boundaries is critical for trust.

Subtasks:
- Define persisted trace and snapshot continuity contract.
- Implement restart replay validation for representative failure points.
- Add power-loss simulation scenarios for partial write, torn frame, and interrupted flush boundaries.
- Build artifact collection for continuity failures with detailed logging.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Restarted replay preserves canonical semantic digest where contract requires.
- Continuity tests cover partial-write, power-loss, and interrupted-run edge cases.
- Gate integrates into CI hard quality checks.

title: Implement hindsight nondeterminism logging ring and flush-on-failure path
description:
Background:
Plan section 6.8.H introduces hindsight logging to capture only external nondeterministic inputs with low overhead.

Subtasks:
- Implement bounded ring buffer for nondeterministic boundary events (for example external IO readiness and signal arrivals).
- Flush ring contents on invariant failure or explicit debug trigger.
- Integrate flushed artifacts into replay and first-divergence diagnostics.
- Add tests proving low steady-state overhead and complete divergence context on failure.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Same deterministic scenario remains digest-stable with hindsight logging enabled.
- Failure artifacts include enough context to reconstruct divergence.
- Ring capacity and flush policy are configurable and documented.

title: Implement multi-tier telemetry modes with semantic-neutral guarantees
description:
Background:
Idea round 3 calls for forensic, ops-light, and ultra-minimal telemetry tiers without semantic drift.

Subtasks:
- Define telemetry tiers and retained event fields per tier.
- Ensure canonical semantic digest computation remains independent of telemetry tier.
- Add fixtures comparing behavior across tiers under identical scenarios.
- Document operational tradeoffs and recommended defaults by profile/resource class.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Telemetry tier changes alter observability cost, not runtime semantics.
- Tier mismatch tests prove digest equivalence on shared fixtures.
- Operators can select tier per deployment with explicit guidance.

title: EPIC: Advanced Alpha Levers and Research Backlog (No Feature Loss)
description:
Background:
The plan includes advanced ideas (formal assurance ladder, lock-free alternatives, cache-oblivious layouts, etc.). These should be pursued via controlled spikes with rollback and proof artifacts.

Run high-EV research tasks that can elevate performance/assurance without semantic compromise.

- explicit baseline/profile/isomorphism artifacts
- fallback path mandatory

- Completion evidence must remain compatible with bd-66l.9 enforcement and traceability index expectations.

title: Pilot formal assurance ladder from golden outputs to bounded model checks to translation validation
description:
Background:
The plan calls for replacing missing compile-time guarantees with layered assurance artifacts.

- Pilot bounded model checks on selected lifecycle/state-machine components.
- Define lightweight translation-validation checks for critical transformations.

- Includes fallback plan if tooling cost outweighs value.
- Leaves behind reusable templates for future formal efforts.

title: Prototype optional Rust-AST zero-drift extractor for transition and invariant artifacts

Plan section 6.8.3B allows an optional zero-drift extractor path to reduce manual transcription drift from Rust semantics.

- Generated artifacts pass parity review before any adoption.
- Clear go/no-go decision and risk note are recorded.

title: Evaluate optional wasm32 determinism-oracle gate for host-coupling detection
description:
Background:
Plan section 10.7.4 defines a high-value optional wasm oracle to expose hidden host coupling and nondeterminism.

Subtasks:
- Add prototype build/run path for core profile under wasm sandbox target.
- Run selected parity fixtures and compare semantic digests against native deterministic mode.
- Document classes of defects this oracle catches and maintenance cost.
- Define criteria for optional ongoing CI inclusion vs on-demand diagnostic use.

- Value/cost decision is documented with evidence.
- If retained, invocation path and artifact expectations are documented.

title: Evaluate lock-free queue and shadow-path equivalence for high-contention messaging paths
description:
Background:
Lock-free fast paths may improve throughput/tail behavior, but only if semantic equivalence and rollback are guaranteed.

Subtasks:
- Implement spike version for candidate queue design.
- Compare against baseline queue under identical fixture/benchmark sets.
- Produce isomorphism and fallback artifacts per optimization-governance rules.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Decision made with measured EV and explicit risk profile.
- Semantic equivalence validated on shared fixture set.
- Safe fallback remains first-class and tested.

title: Study cache-oblivious or locality-aware arena layouts for scheduler hot paths
description:
Background:
Memory layout can materially impact performance across heterogeneous CPU/cache profiles.

Subtasks:
- Evaluate candidate layout strategies for region/task/obligation arenas.
- Benchmark across representative host and embedded targets.
- Document portability impact and maintenance tradeoffs.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Clear go/no-go recommendation with evidence.
- No adoption without semantic neutrality proof.
- Includes rollback and guardrail strategy.

title: Add memory-model litmus suite and cross-compiler codegen checks for critical atomic paths
description:
Background:
Cross-platform correctness for atomics paths needs targeted validation beyond unit tests.

Subtasks:
- Define litmus cases for critical synchronization assumptions.
- Run across compiler/target matrix and compare outcomes.
- Add codegen-diff checks for sensitive kernels where practical.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Litmus suite integrated into non-blocking research or gated checks as appropriate.
- Findings feed directly into profile/runtime design decisions.
- Any unsafe assumption is documented and mitigated.

title: Prototype replay-guided performance regression localization and deterministic circuit-breaker strategy
description:
Background:
Replay artifacts can accelerate localization of performance regressions and guide stable overload mitigation.

Subtasks:
- Correlate replay traces with perf deltas to isolate suspect subsystems.
- Prototype deterministic circuit-breaker behavior for cascading overload scenarios.
- Define adoption criteria and risk boundaries.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Produces actionable workflow for regression triage.
- Circuit-breaker semantics remain deterministic and fixture-testable.
- Recommendation includes operational guardrails and fallback behavior.

title: Research SOS barrier-certificate style bounds for adaptive scheduler safety
description:
Background:
The plan lists SOS-style barrier certificates as a potential assurance lever for starvation bounds under adaptive behavior.

Subtasks:
- Formalize target adaptive behaviors and safety property candidates.
- Evaluate feasibility of offline synthesized admissibility bounds.
- Define practical integration path or explicit rejection rationale.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Produces concrete recommendation with assumptions and limits.
- If adopted, provides artifact format and validation strategy.
- If rejected, documents why and what alternative guardrail replaces it.

title: Evaluate optional alpha tracks (seqlock metadata and EBR/hazard reclamation) with fallback parity checks
description:
Background:
Plan includes optional advanced tracks for parallel profile performance; adoption requires proof and rollback.

Subtasks:
- Prototype seqlock metadata path and evaluate correctness/performance tradeoffs.
- Prototype EBR or hazard-based reclamation path for ownership-sensitive structures.
- Validate fallback paths and parity behavior against baseline locking approach.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Each track has explicit go/no-go decision with evidence.
- Fallback remains implemented and verified.
- No semantic drift is introduced by adoption.

title: Prototype time-virtualization layer for jitter and clock-anomaly replay
description:
Background:
Idea round 3 highlights time virtualization as a lever for reproducing jitter and clock anomalies deterministically.

Subtasks:
- Define virtual-time injection API boundaries and scheduling interactions.
- Extend scenario DSL with clock anomaly events (jitter, stall, jump).
- Build replay tests showing deterministic reproduction of anomaly scenarios.
- Evaluate operational overhead and integration risks.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Provides clear go/no-go recommendation with benchmarked overhead.
- Anomaly scenarios reproduce deterministically across repeated runs.
- Fallback to physical-time mode remains intact and documented.

title: Define hot-reload-safe config boundaries and semantic freeze points
description:
Background:
Idea round 3 proposes hot-reload-safe config boundaries so runtime tuning does not mutate semantics mid-flight.

Subtasks:
- Classify config fields as hot-reload-safe, freeze-at-start, or restart-required.
- Define semantic freeze points where updates are applied atomically.
- Add tests for mid-run update safety and rollback on invalid updates.
- Document operator workflow for safe live tuning.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Config reload behavior is deterministic and policy-driven.
- Unsafe mid-run updates are rejected with explicit diagnostics.
- Replay and semantic digest guarantees remain intact.

title: EPIC: Release, Evidence, and Operational Readiness
description:
Background:
A high-assurance runtime needs repeatable release mechanics plus evidence bundles for audits and regulated contexts.

Goal:
Define release automation, artifact integrity checks, and evidence packaging that map implementation behavior to documented guarantees.

Outputs:
- release runbooks
- signed/checksummed artifacts
- certification-ready evidence skeletons

Why this serves users:
- production confidence for operators
- reduced friction for safety-critical adoption.

Cross-cutting quality contract:
- Child tasks must define and link unit tests, e2e script coverage (when behavioral), and structured log/manifest artifacts or explicit rationale for non-applicability.
- Completion evidence must remain compatible with bd-66l.9 enforcement and traceability index expectations.

title: Implement release automation and integrity artifacts for asx targets
description:
Background:
Releases must be repeatable and verifiable across supported targets.

Subtasks:
- Define build and packaging pipeline for target artifacts.
- Emit checksum and signature bundles for each release asset.
- Define asset naming/versioning conventions and provenance metadata.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Release pipeline is reproducible and documented.
- Integrity metadata is generated automatically.
- Release artifacts map cleanly to CI evidence and version tags.

title: Create release verification and rollback runbook
description:
Background:
Operational users need deterministic post-release validation and safe rollback procedures.

Subtasks:
- Define verification checklist for artifact presence, signatures, and smoke tests.
- Require release-candidate e2e runs (kernel lifecycle, codec equivalence, profile parity, restart continuity, vertical HFT/automotive/router lanes) with archived manifests.
- Define rollback triggers and rollback procedure by release class.
- Define incident-response references for replay/conformance validation post-deploy.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Runbook enables repeatable release validation by any maintainer.
- Rollback path is fast and tested in at least one dry run.
- Includes profile-specific smoke verification guidance.
- Release approval requires complete structured logs and artifact manifests from required e2e runs.

title: Create certification-ready evidence bundle skeletons and mapping templates
description:
Background:
Safety-critical and regulated adopters require structured evidence linking claims to artifacts.

Subtasks:
- Define bundle structure for invariants, tests, conformance, and gate evidence.
- Define mapping templates for standards-oriented documentation (for example ISO-style traceability needs).
- Link bundle sections to traceability index and CI artifact IDs.
- Include canonical pointers to unit/invariant/e2e structured logs, run manifests, parity diffs, and replay bundles.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Bundle skeleton is complete enough for audited release candidates.
- Mappings are explicit and reproducible from repository artifacts.
- No claim exists without a documented evidence location.
- Evidence bundle is sufficient for third-party audit replay of key failures and mitigations.

title: Define C API/ABI stability contract and versioned compatibility process
description:
Background:
C API/ABI stability is adoption-critical, especially for embedded integrators and long-lived deployments.

Subtasks:
- Define public API versioning macros (`ASX_API_VERSION_MAJOR/MINOR/PATCH`) and compatibility policy.
- Define symbol-visibility and header hygiene rules for static/dynamic portability.
- Define config-struct evolution rules (size-field pattern vs frozen structs).
- Implement consumer-shim CI job that compiles against public headers only.
- Define deprecation/migration documentation requirements and release checklist integration.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Stability contract is explicit, versioned, and visible to integrators.
- ABI break detection/check process is enforceable in CI/release workflow.
- Breaking-change process and migration notes requirements are unambiguous.

title: Run API ergonomics validation gate with compilable usage vignettes
description:
Background:
Plan section 7.3.2 adds a pre-lock API usability gate to avoid shipping semantically-correct but hostile C APIs.

Subtasks:
- Implement 3-5 compilable vignette programs covering lifecycle, obligations, budgets, replay, and freestanding hooks.
- Measure boilerplate/footgun burden and discoverability per vignette.
- Propose header/API adjustments where ergonomics are unnecessarily poor.
- Record final ergonomics decision and rationale in API docs before header freeze.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Vignettes compile and run in CI against public headers.
- Ergonomics findings are documented with actionable outcomes.
- Public header freeze cannot proceed without explicit ergonomics sign-off.

title: EPIC: Hard Quality Gates and CI Enforcement
description:
Background:
The plan defines non-negotiable gates. They must be automated and enforced to prevent regressions from entering mainline.

Goal:
Encode all required gates in CI with reproducible artifacts and clear fail reasons.

Gates include:
- portability, OOM semantics, fuzz parity
- embedded matrix, profile parity, semantic-delta budget
- HFT tail/jitter, automotive deadline/watchdog
- crash/restart replay continuity
- warning/static-analysis/bounded-proof gates

Why this serves users:
- transforms policy into enforceable guarantees
- makes trust scalable beyond individual reviewers.

Cross-cutting quality contract:
- Child tasks must define and link unit tests, e2e script coverage (when behavioral), and structured log/manifest artifacts or explicit rationale for non-applicability.
- Completion evidence must remain compatible with bd-66l.9 enforcement and traceability index expectations.

title: Implement CI workflow matrix for build, tests, conformance, profiles, fuzz, embedded, and perf
description:
Background:
Quality policy is only real when encoded in CI. Workflow structure must mirror plan-gate structure.

Subtasks:
- Define jobs for check, unit-invariant, conformance, profile-parity, fuzz-parity, embedded-matrix, perf-tail-deadline, and e2e scenario packs.
- Ensure deterministic artifact naming and retention.
- Ensure failure output is actionable and machine-readable where possible.
- Enforce publication of test run manifests and first-failure summaries for each test lane.

Acceptance Criteria:
- CI runs all required jobs on expected triggers.
- Job outputs are sufficient for triage without rerunning everything locally.
- No critical gate is left as manual-only.
- Missing e2e artifacts/manifests fail the workflow.

title: Implement section 10.7 warning/static-analysis/bounded-model gates
description:
Background:
Plan section 10.7 adds mandatory gates replacing lost Rust compiler guarantees in core kernel paths.

Subtasks:
- Enforce warning-as-error policy across GCC/Clang/MSVC with curated high-signal flags.
- Add static-analyzer job and triage policy (must-fix/waiver/backlog) wired into CI outcomes.
- Add bounded model-check job for small-state transition/cancellation/double-resolve properties.
- Publish rerun commands and artifact expectations for each gate in CI docs.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Section 10.7 gates run automatically and fail correctly on violations.
- Analyzer waivers are explicit, justified, and auditable.
- Bounded-model artifacts are reproducible and attached to failing runs.

title: Encode and enforce full hard quality gate pack from plan section 10.6
description:
Background:
The hard gates are the anti-regression backbone and must include both section 10.6 semantic gates and section 10.7 static/proof gates.

Subtasks:
- Enforce portability matrix, strict exhaustion semantics, differential fuzzing/minimization, embedded matrix, profile parity, tail/jitter, deadline/watchdog, replay continuity, and semantic-delta gates.
- Enforce compiler warning-as-error policies (GCC/Clang/MSVC) and high-signal lint checks.
- Enforce static-analyzer triage policy (must-fix/waiver/backlog rules).
- Enforce bounded model-check job for small-state transition/cancellation/linearity properties.
- Enforce required unit/invariant/e2e script execution and structured manifest/log emission.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Every required gate has explicit pass/fail automation and artifact links.
- Gate failures provide deterministic rerun commands and evidence paths.
- No merge path bypasses mandatory gates unintentionally.
- Gate evaluation fails when required unit/invariant/e2e artifact schema is incomplete.

title: Implement semantic delta budget gate with explicit exception workflow
description:
Background:
Plan requires semantic delta budget equal zero by default to prevent silent behavior erosion.

Subtasks:
- Implement baseline semantic digest comparison policy.
- Define explicit exception metadata and owner approval requirements.
- Integrate gate into CI so unapproved deltas fail fast.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Default behavior rejects non-zero semantic delta.
- Exception path is explicit, auditable, and fixture-scoped.
- Reports clearly identify changed semantic units.

title: Implement evidence-ledger regression dashboard and trends for confidence/fallback metrics
description:
Background:
Long-term quality needs trend visibility, not just per-run pass/fail.

Subtasks:
- Collect and store conformance, fuzz, profile parity, tail/deadline metrics over time.
- Surface trend regressions and confidence/fallback rate changes.
- Provide links to artifacts for each anomaly point.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Dashboard supports release readiness decisions.
- Trend alerts are useful and low-noise.
- Evidence mapping aligns with traceability index.

title: Define and enforce golden performance SLO gates with baseline governance
description:
Background:
Golden SLO gates are explicitly called for to prevent regressions hidden by noisy benchmarks.

Subtasks:
- Define baseline capture protocol and update policy.
- Set p50/p95/p99/p99.9/p99.99 and deadline budgets by profile.
- Enforce budget checks in CI with controlled tolerance policy.

Acceptance Criteria:
- SLO gates are deterministic enough for practical CI use.
- Baseline changes require explicit rationale and audit trail.
- Gate failures include budget deltas and likely culprit subsystems.

title: Implement checkpoint-coverage lint gate for long-running loops
description:
Background:
Plan section 6.8.G requires every long-running loop in kernel paths to include asx_checkpoint or an explicit waiver.

Subtasks:
- Build static lint rule that flags loops missing checkpoint or approved waiver macro.
- Define waiver annotation format with reason code and reviewer metadata.
- Integrate gate into CI and local lint targets.
- Add tests for true positives, false positives, and waiver handling.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Kernel loops without checkpoint/waiver fail CI.
- Waiver path is explicit, searchable, and auditable.
- Rule noise is low enough for sustained enforcement.

title: Implement anti-butchering proof-block gate for semantic-sensitive changes
description:
Background:
Plan section 6.13 requires semantic-sensitive pull requests to include guarantee-substitution notes, proof artifacts, and fallback/isomorphism statements.

Subtasks:
- Define required metadata template for semantic-sensitive changes.
- Implement CI check that fails when required proof fields are missing.
- Link required fields to traceability index and artifact locations.
- Document how to request and review exceptions.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Semantic-sensitive changes cannot merge without complete proof block metadata.
- Metadata links are machine-checkable and reviewer-friendly.
- Exception flow is explicit and auditable.

title: Implement per-target binary-size and cold-start SLO gates
description:
Background:
Idea round 2 includes per-target binary size and cold-start gates as embedded adoption multipliers.

Subtasks:
- Capture size and cold-start baselines for key target profiles and triplets.
- Define budget policy and tolerance windows per profile/resource class.
- Integrate checks into CI with clear delta reporting and reproducible rerun commands.
- Emit structured gate artifacts (target, baseline, delta, suspect modules, run metadata) for trend analysis and release review.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Regressions in size/start metrics fail gate when outside approved budgets.
- Reports identify changed targets and likely contributing modules.
- Baseline updates require explicit rationale and audit trail.
- Gate artifacts are machine-readable and linkable from release evidence bundles.

title: Enforce per-bead evidence linkage contract for unit/e2e/logging completeness
description:
Background:
The hard-part verification rules require every semantic-sensitive implementation bead to carry explicit proof linkage, not only CI-level gating.

Subtasks:
- Define required evidence fields per implementation bead: linked unit tests, linked e2e scripts, expected artifact manifests, and replay/parity references.
- Require linkage against the unit/invariant completeness matrix (bd-1md.12) and canonical e2e suite contract (bd-1md.10) so evidence remains coverage-complete, not ad hoc.
- Add validation tooling that checks bead metadata and notes for required evidence references before status transitions to done.
- Integrate checks with anti-butchering proof-block gate and traceability index updates.
- Provide reviewer/operator guidance for interpreting evidence packs quickly.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Semantic-sensitive beads cannot be marked complete without linked unit/e2e/logging evidence.
- Evidence packs reference explicit unit/invariant obligations and at least one canonical e2e lane per covered semantic surface.
- Validation failures are explicit and actionable.
- Evidence links remain machine-checkable for audit and release workflows.

title: EPIC: Core Semantics and Guarantee Substitution in ANSI C/C99
description:
Background:
Rust compile-time guarantees are absent in C. We must reconstitute equivalent runtime/proof guarantees via explicit mechanisms.

Goal:
Implement asx_core semantic primitives and safety scaffolding with deterministic failure behavior.

Core obligations:
- explicit state authorities
- generation-safe handles and ownership boundaries
- ghost monitors and linearity checks
- strict resource exhaustion semantics
- canonical error taxonomy and stability policy

Why this serves users:
- correctness under pressure for embedded systems
- predictable failure semantics for high-stakes systems
- confidence that performance tuning does not erase guarantees.

Cross-cutting quality contract:
- Child tasks must define and link unit tests, e2e script coverage (when behavioral), and structured log/manifest artifacts or explicit rationale for non-applicability.
- Completion evidence must remain compatible with bd-66l.9 enforcement and traceability index expectations.

title: Implement core API types: status, errors, outcomes, budgets, cancellation, and IDs
description:
Background:
These primitives are shared across all runtime behavior and therefore must be stable, deterministic, and audit-friendly.

Subtasks:
- Define status/error taxonomy with stable code families.
- Define outcome types and ordering semantics.
- Define budget and cancellation core types with explicit failure semantics.
- Define ID formats and generation strategy for handle safety.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Types are fully documented and covered by unit tests.
- Error/status semantics are deterministic and profile-agnostic.
- Public API naming and visibility are consistent.
close_reason: done

title: Implement protothread-style task poll contract and region-arena captured-state safety
description:
Background:
Plan sections 6.8.A and 7.4 require a safe C replacement for async/await that preserves lifecycle semantics without stack-lifetime footguns.

Subtasks:
- Implement coroutine-style task macros (`ASX_CO_BEGIN`, `ASX_CO_YIELD`, `ASX_CO_END`) with explicit resume state.
- Enforce region-arena ownership of captured task state; no malloc-owned suspended state in kernel profiles.
- Add explicit yield-safety lint gate that flags non-const locals/raw internal pointers persisting across yield unless waived.
- Define spawn contract for state sizing/finalization so suspended tasks cannot leak on region close.
- Add tests for suspend/resume ordering, cancellation checkpoints, and region-close cleanup.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Poll contract is deterministic and fixture-tested.
- No leaked task state on cancellation or region closure.
- Yield-safety violations are caught automatically by CI lint/static checks.
- Macro workflow is documented with explicit do/dont examples.
close_reason: done

title: Implement thread-affinity guards and explicit cross-thread transfer certificates
description:
Background:
Plan section 6.8.C requires a concrete replacement for Rust Send and Sync protections.

Subtasks:
- Add affinity domain tags to mutable runtime-owned objects.
- Add debug/hardened boundary checks that trap wrong-thread mutable access deterministically.
- Implement explicit transfer API with atomic ownership handoff metadata.
- Add misuse tests for stale-domain access, double-transfer, and missing-transfer paths.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Cross-thread misuse fails deterministically with stable error diagnostics.
- Legitimate transfer path is explicit, auditable, and replay-visible.
- Safety checks are profile-gated with documented production overhead.
close_reason: done

title: Implement ghost borrow ledger and ghost determinism monitor
description:
Background:
Plan sections 6.10 and 6.8.E/H call for debug-only ghost systems that recover lost Rust confidence.

Subtasks:
- Implement ghost borrow ledger with shared and exclusive epoch tracking per handle.
- Reject exclusive writes while shared borrow epochs are active.
- Implement ghost determinism monitor that validates scheduler key ordering and per-run digest stability.
- Wire violation events into structured diagnostics and replay artifacts.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Known borrow/protocol violations are detected with deterministic repro logs.
- Determinism monitor catches ordering drift in dedicated tests.
- Debug/hardened profiles enable monitors; release profile behavior is explicitly documented.
close_reason: done

title: Implement runtime hook contract for allocator, reactor, clock, entropy, and log sinks
description:
Background:
Plan sections 7.6 and 7.10 require explicit runtime hooks plus deterministic-mode boundary enforcement.

Subtasks:
- Define hook contract for allocator, reactor, clock, entropy, and logging callbacks.
- Enforce deterministic-mode rules: no ambient entropy and logical-time/recorded-event boundary behavior.
- Add ghost-reactor replay mode for deterministic readiness replays.
- Implement optional steady-state allocator seal (`asx_runtime_seal_allocator`) for hardened/no-allocation profiles.
- Add validation tests for missing hooks, invalid hook behavior, deterministic constraints, and allocator-seal traps.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Hook contract is fully documented and test-covered.
- Deterministic mode rejects forbidden entropy/reactor/time paths with stable errors.
- Replay mode remains semantically equivalent to live mode for shared fixtures.
- Allocator-seal behavior is profile-gated and regression-tested.
close_reason: done

title: Implement must-use enforcement and task-local contextual error ledger
description:
Background:
Plan section 7.3.3 requires explicit substitutes for Rust question-mark and Result ergonomics plus dropped-result safety, anchored to core API and transition-authority surfaces.

Subtasks:
- Apply compiler-enforced must-use attributes to transition and acquisition APIs defined in core types (bd-hwb.1) and authority-table surfaces (bd-hwb.3).
- Implement ASX_TRY-style helper that records deterministic file/line/op breadcrumbs in a task-local zero-allocation ledger.
- Ensure ledger output is deterministic and replay-compatible.
- Add tests for dropped-result violations and multi-hop error propagation context quality.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Must-use violations are surfaced at compile/lint time where supported.
- Must-use coverage report enumerates protected APIs and transition/acquisition surfaces.
- Error propagation preserves actionable context without heap allocation.
- Deterministic-mode replay includes stable error-ledger behavior.
close_reason: done

title: Implement region-scoped fault containment policy for hardened/production profiles
description:
Background:
Plan section 12.2 requires deterministic containment options beyond debug fail-fast semantics.

Subtasks:
- Implement region-poison/isolation state transitions and parent-outcome propagation policy.
- Ensure containment path is deterministic and does not permit partial-corruption continuation.
- Add profile controls: debug fail-fast vs hardened containment behavior.
- Add tests/fixtures for containment transitions and recovery boundaries.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Fault containment behavior is explicit, deterministic, and profile-gated.
- Containment path preserves semantic integrity and traceability.
- Misconfiguration paths fail safely with stable diagnostics.

title: Enforce public API documentation contract (pre/post/error/ownership/thread-safety)
description:
Background:
Phase-3 exit criteria require every public API touched to include complete behavioral documentation, not just signatures.

Subtasks:
- Define mandatory doc fields per public API: preconditions, postconditions, error codes, ownership model, thread-safety guarantees.
- Add lint/check tooling to fail when required doc fields are missing or stale for changed public APIs.
- Link docs to misuse catalog entries and error-family mappings.
- Add reviewer checklist and examples of acceptable documentation quality.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Public API changes cannot pass gates with incomplete docs.
- Documentation quality is machine-checkable and reviewer-auditable.
- Consumers can use APIs safely without consulting internal source code.

title: Implement and verify outcome severity lattice plus budget algebra/exhaustion semantics
description:
Background:
Outcome joins and budget rules are central semantic contracts that must exactly match extracted behavior.

Subtasks:
- Implement outcome join and severity comparison operations.
- Implement budget composition, reduction, and exhaustion behavior.
- Add edge-case tests for empty/max/boundary and conflicting outcomes.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Unit tests demonstrate deterministic and associative behavior where required.
- Exhaustion semantics are explicit and failure-atomic.
- Matches canonical fixture expectations.
close_reason: done

title: Implement transition authority tables for region/task/obligation/cancellation state machines
description:
Background:
State-machine authority tables are the primary substitute for compile-time typestate guarantees.

Subtasks:
- Encode legal transitions and explicit forbidden transitions.
- Enforce preconditions and postconditions on each transition API.
- Generate transition legality tests from invariant schema where possible.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Every lifecycle domain has explicit transition map.
- Illegal transitions return stable deterministic errors.
- Transition tests include positive and negative paths.
close_reason: done

title: Implement cleanup-stack and ownership/handle safety mechanisms
description:
Background:
C lacks RAII and borrow checking. We need explicit mechanisms to preserve lifecycle and aliasing discipline.

Subtasks:
- Implement cleanup-stack primitives for deterministic unwind and rollback.
- Implement generation-based handle validation and stale-handle detection.
- Implement optional debug quarantine mode for reuse hardening.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Cleanup behavior is deterministic and failure-atomic.
- Handle misuse paths are test-covered with explicit errors.
- Ownership assumptions are documented in API contract notes.
close_reason: done

title: Implement ghost safety monitors for protocol and linearity invariants
description:
Background:
Ghost monitors provide lightweight runtime checks to recover part of Rust-level protocol confidence in debug/hardened modes.

Subtasks:
- Implement protocol monitor for lifecycle sequencing violations.
- Implement linearity monitor for reserve/commit/abort misuse.
- Integrate monitor outputs into test diagnostics and traces.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Monitor violations are deterministic and actionable.
- Overhead behavior is documented per safety profile.
- Tests demonstrate detection of known violation patterns.
close_reason: Ghost safety monitors fully implemented and tested: protocol monitor for lifecycle sequencing violations (region/task/obligation transitions), linearity monitor for obligation double-use and leak detection, ring buffer with overflow handling, query interface, and integration with lifecycle/scheduler/quiescence. 21 tests, all passing.

title: Implement strict resource-contract engine and deterministic exhaustion behavior
description:
Background:
Resource exhaustion is a major C failure mode. The plan requires deterministic, non-corrupting behavior at all boundaries.

Subtasks:
- Implement configurable ceilings (memory, queue depth, timer nodes, trace events).
- Implement admission/backpressure/reject decision points with stable error codes.
- Add failure-atomic rollback semantics at boundary transitions.

Acceptance Criteria:
- No partial state corruption on exhaustion paths.
- Boundary tests cover arena alloc, queue growth, timer ops, and obligation ops.
- Behavior is consistent across profiles and reproducible in replay.
close_reason: done

title: Finalize error stability policy, safety profiles, and deterministic time/entropy fault modes
description:
Background:
Error policy and deterministic boundary rules are core substitutes for Rust-level guarantees in C.

Subtasks:
- Define canonical error families and compatibility policy (stable meanings, additive growth rules).
- Implement compiler-enforced must-use behavior for transition/acquisition APIs.
- Implement zero-allocation contextual error ledger (`file/line/op`) for deterministic failure propagation breadcrumbs.
- Define safety profiles (debug-ghost/hardened/release-fast) with explicit invariants and overhead envelopes.
- Implement deterministic time/entropy/clock-anomaly fault injection hooks and fixtures.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Error policy is versioned and documented.
- Must-use and context-ledger behavior are test-covered and deterministic.
- Each safety profile has explicit invariants and intended use.
- Fault-injection paths are covered by automated tests linked to replay artifacts.
close_reason: done

title: Implement adaptive-decision contract with expected-loss model, evidence ledger, and deterministic fallback
description:
Background:
Plan section 6.11 requires adaptive choices to remain explainable and replay-safe.

Subtasks:
- Define expected-loss decision framework and allowed decision surfaces.
- Emit evidence records for adaptive choices and confidence inputs.
- Implement deterministic fallback path when confidence is insufficient.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Adaptive behavior is auditable and replay-compatible.
- Fallback path is always available and test-covered.
- Decision outputs are stable enough for regression monitoring.

title: Implement security and safety posture checks for pointer ownership and invariant violation handling
description:
Background:
Section 12 now includes explicit threat-model boundaries and production fault-containment expectations in addition to debug fail-fast behavior.

Subtasks:
- Document and enforce pointer ownership and stale-handle misuse defenses.
- Add misuse tests for illegal transitions, stale handles, unsafe pointer paths, and malformed-input boundaries.
- Codify in-scope vs out-of-scope threat boundaries for kernel responsibilities.
- Implement deterministic production containment path (region poison/isolation policy) so failures can be scoped without undefined behavior.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Safety posture requirements are test-enforced and profile-aware.
- Failure behavior is deterministic, visible, and bounded by policy.
- Security-relevant misuse paths have regression coverage with reproducible artifacts.
- Threat boundary documentation maps directly to tests and explicit non-goals.

title: EPIC: Build System, Portability Matrix, and Repository Scaffold
description:
Background:
The runtime must compile and behave predictably across host and constrained targets. Build portability is a first-class requirement, not cleanup work.

Goal:
Establish build/repo infrastructure for GCC/Clang/MSVC plus embedded cross-target matrix, including QEMU validation harness.

Must preserve:
- dependency-free core assumptions
- profile-aware compile paths
- reproducible, diagnosable failures

Why this serves users:
- HFT teams need deterministic reproducible builds
- embedded teams need cross-target confidence before deployment
- maintainers need fast feedback loops with clear failure surfaces.

Cross-cutting quality contract:
- Child tasks must define and link unit tests, e2e script coverage (when behavioral), and structured log/manifest artifacts or explicit rationale for non-applicability.
- Completion evidence must remain compatible with bd-66l.9 enforcement and traceability index expectations.

title: Scaffold repository layout and module boundaries for include/src/tests/fixtures/tools/docs
description:
Background:
The codebase structure must enforce architectural boundaries from day one to prevent accidental coupling.

Subtasks:
- Create canonical directory map for include, src, tests, fixtures, tools, docs.
- Define ownership for each module boundary and allowed dependencies.
- Define naming conventions for APIs, internal files, and test fixtures.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Layout aligns with proposed architecture and parity tracking needs.
- No ambiguous module ownership.
- New contributors can infer where code belongs without guessing.
close_reason: Completed scaffold contract details: canonical directory map, explicit module ownership/dependency boundaries, and naming conventions in docs/PHASE2_SCAFFOLD_MANIFEST.md

title: Implement primary Makefile workflow and optional CMake generator strategy
description:
Background:
Build and test commands must be stable and scriptable across environments.

Subtasks:
- Define make targets for build, lint, format-check, test, conformance, fuzz-smoke, profile-parity.
- Document optional CMake generation path for consumers needing IDE/toolchain integration.
- Define reproducibility expectations (flags, target profiles, deterministic options).

Acceptance Criteria:
- Make targets cover all quality gates in plan section 10.6.
- Commands are CI-compatible and locally reproducible.
- Optional CMake path does not become the primary maintenance burden.
close_reason: done

title: Implement compiler and platform matrix scripts (GCC/Clang/MSVC, 32/64-bit, endian variants)
description:
Background:
Portability failures found late are expensive and destabilizing. Matrix checks must be early and continuous.

Subtasks:
- Define matrix build scripts for GCC, Clang, and MSVC.
- Include 32-bit and 64-bit targets where supported.
- Add endian-variance checks and compile-time assumptions validation.
- Document expected warning policy and failure handling.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Matrix scripts are deterministic and produce parseable logs.
- Unsupported targets fail with actionable diagnostics.
- No compiler-specific assumptions leak into core without explicit guards.
close_reason: Implemented deterministic compiler/platform matrix scripts with parseable JSONL logs and endian assumption checks

title: Implement embedded cross-target matrix for router-class triplets
description:
Background:
Embedded usefulness must be validated on real target architectures, not inferred from host builds.

Subtasks:
- Add cross-build scripts for mipsel-openwrt-linux-musl, armv7-openwrt-linux-muslgnueabi, and aarch64-openwrt-linux-musl.
- Define profile flags and resource-class defaults for these targets.
- Capture binary-size and startup metrics needed for regression tracking.

Acceptance Criteria:
- All triplets build cleanly with reproducible logs.
- Failing targets report missing assumptions explicitly.
- Output artifacts are suitable for CI and smoke deployment.
close_reason: Implemented embedded triplet matrix runner, resource-class defaults, and reproducible metric logs; real run emits explicit unsupported diagnostics when toolchains are missing

title: Create QEMU harness for router-class scenario and replay validation
description:
Background:
Cross-compilation alone is insufficient; runtime behavior on target-like environments is required.

Subtasks:
- Build QEMU execution harness for key router-class targets.
- Run scenario DSL suites and replay checks under emulation.
- Emit detailed logs and artifact bundles for failed runs.
